bestBHT.bht: In this account, a group of violent men formed a conspiracy, bound themselves under a curse, and vowed to kill Paul. This wicked oath revealed the moral depravity of the Jews at the time. While they could easily obtain absolution from their vows, their commitment to murder was evident. Conversely, Paul found peace and assurance in his imprisonment, as his enemies were consumed by active malice. This story serves as a caution to defend God's glory passionately.

Henry Alford: 12.] Wetstein and Lightfoot adduce instances of similar conspiracies,—not to eat or drink till some object be gained. See 1 Sam. xiv. 24 ff.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: curse . . . that they would neither eat . . . fill they had killed
Albert Barnes: And bound themselves under a curse...they invoked a curse on themselves, or devoted themselves to destruction, if they did not do it.
Under various pretences they could easily be freed from such oaths, and it was common to take them.
This was a most wicked oath. It was a deliberate purpose to commit murder; and it shows the desperate state of morals among the Jews at that time.
Marvin Vincent: Banded together [ποιησαντες συστροφην]. Lit., having made a conspiracy.
Bound themselves under a curse [ανεθεματισαν εαυτους]. Lit., anathematized or cursed themselves; invoked God's curse on themselves if they should violate their vow.
In case of failure, they could procure absolution from their oath by the Rabbis.
John Calvin: This history doth teach that zeal is so bloody in hypocrites, that they weigh not what is lawful for them, but they run carelessly whithersoever their lust doth carry them.
The same blindness and blockishness doth at this day prick forward the Papists, so that they think nothing unlawful for them in destroying us.
Furthermore, seeing Satan doth drive them headlong into their own destruction, how shameful is then our sluggishness, when as we scarce move one finger in maintaining the glory of God?
Philip Schaff: The contrast is great between the peaceful assurance thus secretly given to the faith of the apostle in his place of imprisonment and the active malignity of his enemies in the city.

These violent men bound themselves with a dreadful oath (kherem, חֵדֶם , ἀνάθεμα ), that is, they invoked the curse of God upon themselves in the event of their violating their vow, binding themselves neither to eat nor drink until they had murdered Paul, the enemy of their race.

In the case of such fearful vows, by no means uncommon in that wild time of disorder and hatred, the Talmud, however, provided a loophole of escape for those who so rashly took this burden on themselves.
Archibald T. Robertson: Banded together (ποιησαντες συστροφην). See on Acts 19:40 (riot), but here conspiracy, secret combination, binding together like twisted cords.
Bound themselves under a curse (ανεθεματισαν εαυτους). First aorist active indicative of αναθεματιζω, a late word, said by Cremer and Thayer to be wholly Biblical or ecclesiastical.
Drink (πειν=πιειν). Second aorist active infinitive of πινω. For this shortened form see Robertson, Grammar, p. 343.
John Gill: these men swore to it, bound themselves with an oath, or wished they might be an anathema, accursed of God, and cut off from his people; they imprecated the most dreadful evils upon themselves.

these were a set of zealots, who in imitation of Phinehas, and pretending the glory of God, took upon them to take away the lives of men, without any, judicial procedure, or the authority of the civil magistrate
it was a pretty easy thing to be freed from oaths and vows, among the Jews, whose doctors had a power to absolve men from them
John Wesley: Such execrable vows were not uncommon among the Jews.
And if they were prevented from accomplishing what they had vowed, it was an easy matter to obtain absolution from their rabbis.

bhtAttempts.bht: A group of violent and zealous men in Acts 23:12 formed a secret conspiracy, invoking God's curse upon themselves if they failed to carry out their evil plot to kill Paul. This wicked oath demonstrated the moral depravity of the Jews at that time. Although they could easily find ways to be freed from such vows, their desperate commitment to murder was clear. On the contrary, Paul found peace and assurance in the midst of his imprisonment, while his enemies in the city were consumed by active malice. This passage reveals the dangerous lengths to which hypocrites in their zealous blindness will go, willing to break any law or commit any atrocity for what they perceive as righteous causes. It serves as a caution for us to be vigilant and firm in defending God's glory.

In Acts 23:12, a group of violent men formed a conspiracy, binding themselves under a curse and vowing to kill Paul. Their wicked oath showcased the moral depravity of the Jews during that time. While they had means to be released from their vows, their dedication to murder remained steadfast. In contrast, Paul found solace and certainty in his imprisonment, while his adversaries were driven by bitter enmity. This account serves as a reminder to be resolute in the defense of God's honor.
